Measure.Description: 2 blocks of 48 five-note melodies; 2AFC; Different trials differed by different combinations of 4, 3, 2, or 1 notes
Music.Lesson: Minimal (less than 4.5 years), no significant differences between groups
Notes: Mann-Whiteney U = 140.5, p < 0.05; two-tailed t(21.86)= 2.45, p < 0.05, d = 0.93

Measure.Description: Modified version of the Melodic Comparison subtest of the Musical Ear Test; piano melodies containing 3-8 notes at 100 bpm. Melodies presented in pairs, judge whether identical. Authors came up with the register test. 26 trials per condition with 13 violations each
Music.Lesson: Some participants received musical training, but total years of training not significantly different across groups
Notes: They had a main linear regression result but also did Mann-Whiteney tests for different trial types. beta = 0.09, t = 3.32, p < 0.001; Comes from mixed effect model; not sure if this is standardized

Measure.Description: two-tone sequences, first tone always C5; hear a pair and respond whether second tone is same or different; 130 same and 130 different trials
Music.Lesson: Both groups not significantly different in years of musical training
Notes: F(1, 31) = 7.7, p = 0.009, graph only has specific breakdowns by cents

Measure.Description: standard stimuli at 150 Hz, 16 target randing from 150.5 to 158 Hz in 0.5 steps.  Two-interval forced-choice task. Participants indicate whether higher frequency was presented in first or second interval; 320 trials
Music.Lesson: Limited to little (>3 years) or no music experience
Notes: No significant differences

Measure.Description: hear two sequential intervals, one contains a reference pitch, one contains a comparison (higher F0). Identify which interval had higher pitch
Music.Lesson: non-musicians received less than three years of musical training; 11 English-speaking musicians not included here.
Notes: no significant differences; no stats reported, might need to extract from graph, T_se = 0.0728, NT_se = 0.2226

Measure.Description: 100 pairs of chordal arpeggios; half contains chords with different thirds (major detuned up) half contains the same chord; participants judge whether the two are same; "detect chordal detuning at a perceptual level"
Music.Lesson: non-musicians received less than three years of musical training; 11 English-speaking musicians not included here.
Notes: no significant differences observed; plot only has broken down by type of change

Measure.Description: two pair of notes, first interval C5-G5; second interval F#5-C#6; on different trials C#6 altered by different cents of change; participants judge whether same or different; 160 no change trials and 240 change trials
Music.Lesson: both groups did not differ significantly in length of musical training
Notes: F(1, 30) = 1.574, p = 0.219; graph only has specific breakdowns by cents

Measure.Description: Part of MET. 52 trials, each piano melodic phase contains 3-8 notes, participants judge whether two phrases in a trial are identical
Music.Lesson: 396 had no private music lesson history; on average 2.6 years of private music lessons
Notes: tonal native speakers performed significantly better, F(2, 513) = 10.71, p < 0.001; number of correct?

Measure.Description: Part of MET. 52 tirals, 4-11 beats played with wood block; participants judge whether two phrases in a trial are identical
Music.Lesson: 397 had no private music lesson history; on average 2.6 years of private music lessons
Notes: performed similarly, F(2, 513) = 1.95, p = 1.43

Measure.Description: pairs of two-note melodic intervals. Standard interval has C5 and G5. second interval began on F#5, the note following can be same, higher, or lower. Modifications are 25, 50, 100, 200, or 400 cents. Participants judge whether intervals are the same
Music.Lesson: limited musical skills matched across groups
Notes: tonal language speakers performed significantly better; t(22) = 2.99, p < .01ï¼› plot is not very informative

Measure.Description: two 1-sec sine-wave notes separated by a 1-sec pause; the first note is always a C5 and second note are 50% same, 25% higher, 25% lower, includes 25, 50, 100, 200, 400,600, and 800 cent changes
Music.Lesson: limited musical skills matched across groups
Notes: no significant differences

Measure.Description: pairs of two-note melodic intervals. Standard interval has C5 and G5. second interval began on F#5, the note following can be same, higher, or lower.Modifications are 25, 50, 100, 200, or 400 cents
Music.Lesson: similar in terms of musical training across groups
Notes: tonal language speakers performed significantly better, t(20) = 1.92, p < 0.05

Measure.Description: two 1-sec sine-wave notes separated by a 1-sec pause; the first note is always a C5 and second note are 50% same, 25% higher, 25% lower, includes 25, 50, 100, 200, 400,600, and 800 cent changes
Music.Lesson: similar in terms of musical training across groups
Notes: no significant differences

Measure.Description: two melodies that are either identical, or different by one tone or several tones; task created by the Music and Brain Imaging lab at Harvard Medical School
Music.Lesson: an additional 24 musicians for each group were included in the study but not included here
Notes: Percent correct

Measure.Description: staircase procedure. Two short tones and judge whether second tone was higher or lower; difficulty adapted to performance; value indicates participants' frequency sensitivity (lower = better)
Music.Lesson: an additional 24 musicians for each group were included in the study but not included here
Notes: pitch percision in Hz

Measure.overall: Montreal Battery of Evaluation of Amusia
Measure.Description: three subtests aimed at pitch processing (scale, contour, and interval), three on rhythm and short-memory; half same, half different
Music.Lesson: no significant difference in musical training across groups
Notes: MBEA accuracy

Measure.Description: first subtests at discrimination between musical melodies, second subtest at discrimination between different rhythms; half same, half different
Music.Lesson: no significant differences in musical training across two groups
Notes: MET accuracy, there is also break down of mean and sd for subtest scale, contour, and interval

Measure.Description: 21 different sequences, each containing 5 successive tones. All tones played at C6 for standard trial. In conparison sequence, fourth tone was altered, 1.56 cents to 25 cents. Participants indicate yes or no for change
Music.Lesson: both groups matched in terms of musical training experience; on average two years
Notes: overall rejection rate did not differ signidicantly, t(47) = 1.28, p = 0.21; tonal speakers however performed significantly worse on several categories of tasks when being looked at individually; manuscript only has error bars for more detailed breakdowns (ie different cents of pitch change)

Measure.overall: Montreal Battery of Evaluation of Amusia
Measure.Description: Six tests with each containing 30 same-different classification trials in which a standard melody was followed by a comparison melody; 3 tests for melody, for different trials, one note was altered ( out of scale, out of contour, out of interval); three t
Music.Lesson: both groups matched in terms of musical training experience, on average two years
Notes: no significant group effect, F(1, 47) = 1.66, p = 0.20, however, see Table 2 for breakdown of specific tests, non-tonal speakers performed better on out of the scale melody comparison test, while the two groups did not differ significantly on contour and interval melody comparison tasks

Measure.overall: Montreal Battery of Evaluation of Amusia
Notes: ns

Criteria: F0 DL (%)- minimum percent of change
Measure.Description: 3AFC, three sequential intervals, two containing an indentical reference tone and one contains a higher comparison; identify the interval that contains the higher sounding pitch; deltaF0 calculated using adaptive algorithm
Music.Lesson: 18 non-tonal language speaking musicians were also included in the study but not included here
Notes: tonal speakers did better than non-tonal speakers; lower value means better performance

Measure.Description: forty pairs of short tonal melodies (6 notes each); half contained melody pairs that were identical, other half contained melodies in which a single tone was detuned (sharp or flat by 1/2 or 1/4 semitones)
Music.Lesson: 18 non-tonal language speaking musicians were also included in the study but not included here
Notes: tonal speakers did better on the 1/2 semitone trials but not 1/4 semitone trials

Criteria: F0 DL (%)- minimum percent of change
Measure.Description: Same as Bidelman 2013 F0 difference task
Music.Lesson: 21 non-tonal musicians were included in the study but not here
Notes: tonal speakers outperformed non-tonal speakers, p = 0.003; T_se = 0.11,NT_se = 0.9

Measure.Description: AX discrimination paradigm, C4 followed by either C4 or C4 deviant by 7, 13, 25, 50, 100 (1 semitone), and 200 cents; participants judge whether two tones are same or difference, 144 trials with 72 same
Music.Lesson: 15 musicians for both non-tonal and tonal groups were included in the study but not here
Notes: Results are not broken down separately by musical experience. Overall no difference but musical training interacts with language; sensitivity index d'

Measure.Description: standard and target stimuli each containing two notes; standard has C4 and G4, target starts with F#4 followed by another; C#5 would be identical interval, different intervals C5 altered by 7, 13, 25, 50, 100, or 200 cents
Music.Lesson: 15 musicians for both non-tonal and tonal groups were included in the study but not here
Notes: Again, results not broken down by musical experience; the authors claimed that overall there's no difference in performance; however, musical training improved performance of tonal speakers only

Measure.Description: pitch of the same downbeat as off-beat was mistuned by a quarter tone without tonal/syntactic violation (unlike Study 1 to get rid of ceiling effect); 12 congruent, 12 incongruent
Music.Lesson: did not differ in musical training significantly
Notes: no significant group differences

Measure.Description: half the melodies contain a silence of 5/7 of the beat duration prior to the first downbeat in the third bar of the four bar melody, 12 congruent pairs, 12 incongruent pairs
Music.Lesson: did not differ in musical training significantly
Notes: no significant group differences

Measure.Description: the pitch of the same downbeat violated the tonal/syntactic relationship when considering the rest of the melody, 12 congruent pairs, 12 incongruent pairs
Music.Lesson: There seems to be a slight difference in training but the out of key scores were adjusted based on that
Notes: tonal speaker advantage

Measure.Description: half the melodies contain a silence of 5/7 of the beat duration prior to the first downbeat in the third bar of the four bar melody, 12 congruent pairs, 12 incongruent pairs
Music.Lesson: Slight differences across groups; Cantonese speakers had on average a bit more training
Notes: no significant group differences

Measure.Description: pitch of the same downbeat as off-beat was mistuned by a quarter tone with tonal & syntactic violation; 12 congruent, 12 incongruent
Music.Lesson: Slight differences across groups; Cantonese speakers had on average a bit more training
Notes: no significant group differences. Note that this task includes both mistuning and beat misalignment

Measure.overall: Montreal Battery of Evaluation of Amusia
Measure.Description: scale, contour, interval, rhythm, meter, memory subtests
Music.Lesson: 8 musicians for each group was included in study but not here
Notes: tonal speaker advantage overall

Measure.overall: Montreal Battery of Evaluation of Amusia

Measure.Description: descending and ascending major and minor musical intervals; 12 same and 12 different interval combos (4 contour and interval differed, 4 interval differed, 4 contour differed)
Music.Lesson: participants had little to no musical training
Notes: no significant group difference; unit. is accuracy

Measure.Description: tones ranged from 392 to 416 Hz by steps of 2Hz. All tones are paired with lowest tone
Music.Lesson: participants had little to no musical training
Notes: no significant group difference; unit is minimum discernable difference (Hz)

Music.Lesson: musicians excluded
musicians excluded
non-musicians
We excluded participants with more than three years of musical training
We excluded participants with more than three years of musical training
